{"question":"What concept did the author not understand about the world when they were a child?","answer":"The author didn't understand the degree to which the returns for performance are superlinear.","chunk":"One of the most important things I didn't understand about the world when I was a child is the degree to which the returns for performance are superlinear.","chunk_id":"3bbef20e2e9694dcf8e12a7c45426ff0"}

{"question":"What misconception does the text address regarding returns?","answer":"The text addresses the misconception that returns are linear, where you get out what you put in, which is rarely true.","chunk":"Teachers and coaches implicitly told us the returns were linear. \"You get out,\" I heard a thousand times, \"what you put in.\" They meant well, but this is rarely true. If your product is only half as good as your competitor's, you don't get half as many customers. You get no customers, and you go out of business.","chunk_id":"a9e8cdfb42e07e3fafbce6b69e79ed53"}
